transcription_data.text: Welcome to Reconstructed Faith, a podcast where we talk about truth you can build your life on. We hope to dive into the hard conversations of life and faith and seek out reasonable, substantive answers. My name is Colson Lechner, and I'm joined by Chris Legge and Brent Starnes. This is Reconstructed Faith. Welcome back to the Reconstructed Faith podcast. My name is Colson Lechner alongside my partners in crime today, Chris Sheridan and Chris Legge. Today we're talking about something that I don't enjoy talking about, but I think it's worth talking about because these types of things that we're going to discuss on a podcast today can cause deconstruction and people to think pretty critically. And this revolves around the idea of church leaders falling or making decisions that disqualify them from ministry. And so this is kind of, there's a guy in Texas named Aaron Ivey. He was a worship pastor. And so I'll just read kind of the lead line and then we can talk more about this. But it was just saying on Monday, February 5th, Aaron Ivey was fired from staff after it came to light that he engaged in inappropriate and explicit ongoing text messages with an adult male. So it's always, I mean, it's heavy to hear about that because he, I mean, I think he's been an elder and a pastor for years in Austin, Texas. And we were talking before he recorded, you know, as a worship leader. Yeah. So anyway, I know Chris Legge, you were saying, you know, it might be worth us talking about this. Why do you think it's worth us spending a little bit of time talking about something like this? Well, I think there's a lot of different ways or at least several different ways that this could feed into people deconstructing in their own faith. And I even, you know, wonder, you know, I haven't heard, he has not, I don't think put out any type of statement or comment personally, but even is this, does this in any way represent him deconstructing his faith or or something like that? And if that's the case, when that, when and if that comes out, maybe we can talk about that or discuss that. But, but you're dealing with certainly, you know, one, you have had now a leader, essentially what we would say is, you know, two different headings. Again, this is the kind of my brain is going all over the place. But one is, uh, is he, you know, the church has decided he's been doing something morally wrong. I think there might be some debate and this might even go back to our, you know, is the Bible, whatever is the Bible, what did we end up using sinful or whatever is the Bible immoral by today's standards. Yeah. Um, and so that's one that I would say that's a, that's an issue for sure is, you know, what was, did the Bible push him, did church push him into pretending to not be something that he was, um, that, that in the end it turns out, you know, he was gay and he should have just lived that life. And that this is what I would expect a secular message to be. He should have just lived out that life. And only because of the, you know, the failings of the church being bigoted or, uh, homophobic or something like that is why that's the case. I, I don't love that argument for a couple of reasons. to the place where we should only be believing in Christ in the Messiah who, who can fulfill that,
who can, who can actually, um, we can actually put our faith in. Yes. I was thinking this is
kind of a silly example, but well, for one thing, I'll also reminding us that Aaron Ivy's life is
an over his journey is still ongoing. Totally. Yeah. We're right now reading a headline. And so
my thought was you could have written a headline in the middle of, you know, man after God's own
heart caught in scandal of, you know, another man's wife with David or well, you know, well
respected prophet, angry enough to die that God won't judge people or, you know, Jonah or, or Peter
like, you know, prominent disciple denies it even new G it's like, we are all, we should have this
big sign up over our heads. It says work in progress. Cause we're all a work in progress.
And, um, at any given point, you know, I'm just, I'm still on this side of heaven.
What makes me, what makes me sad for a situation like this. And again, I don't know the details.
So please, you know, as more details come out, some of this may be wrong, but, um, but man,
what makes me so sad with this story as, as with Robbie's story is that it seems like he was just
hiding it or, or denying it or making all kinds of promises. And I just, I just, it breaks my
heart that he didn't, I mean, again, I know, I don't know this. Maybe there's going to be 20,
maybe there's 20 people at that church or like, no, we were praying with him. We were talking with
him. We were working with him. This was just his struggle. This is where he struggled. This was his
temptation. This was his addiction. This was his whatever. And man, we were walking with him the
whole time. Then I, if I hear that, I, my, my attitude on this will change a lot. It sounds like
from what got reported that, that he has been called on this, he's been offered help
and he has chosen to not do what he needed to do to deal with this issue. And instead
just continued to try to hide it now for, you know, over a decade. It looked like from the,
from the articles that the first conversation about this happened like in 2011.
But it's, it's hard to know whether they're saying, no, we've gone back and discovered it
that the 2011, or if it was, you know, whatever. And, you know, I also, I also, you know, it really,
it really is sad that it's, you know, I know there's not a difference probably in the kingdom
ledger for some of this, but, but man, it just, it does certainly feel like a difference when
you're talking about, I blew it, I messed up. And I've been manipulating minors into sexual conduct
because I, you know, I feel like somewhere in there, there probably is a line to say,
I, there were plenty of opportunities to avoid this step along the way. And I chose not to do it.
So again, I'm not, I'm not drawing some theological distinction there, more of a behavioral and even
consequential distinction. And, and I do think it's appropriate for the church to say, hey, based on
what we've discovered, you know, we're, we're coming alongside him. We want to love him. And we have
reported his behavior to the proper authorities. And we have, you know, released him from his
contract here at the church. Again, all of those things are true, can be true simultaneously.
And it doesn't mean we hate him. Like we love him.
That's exactly right. That's exactly right. And I suspect there will be plenty of people,
and it doesn't mean this is one of those tough ones. People really wrestle with this. I know
they do when someone deconstructs or whatever, or in this case kind of falls in their faith.
It's, it's the same thing. Like, dude, does that mean I need to not sing their music?
Does that mean I need to not, you know, listen to their stuff or, or sing their stuff or listen to
their, and, and I for one believe that that is not a necessary consequence. I get it. I certainly
get it. At the same time, I'm like, man, I, I would hate for someone to say, because of sin
in someone's life, we can no longer listen to them proclaim truth because the early,
the early church thought about that and came to the conclusion that the message is what is important
about the Christian faith, not the messenger outside of Jesus, that our faith, like you were
saying, our faith is never in the messenger. It is in the message. But man, is that easier said
than done for us as humans. Right. I think when I heard for the first time years ago that Jonathan
Edwards owned slaves, right? That really bothered me. Like, Oh man, really? Or that Martin Luther
King Jr. had an affair. Like those things. Like I just go, ah, that really, it doesn't,
it doesn't, like you said, take away what they said, but it complicates it as far as like,
this would be so much easier and believable if you weren't, you know, also, or like the founding
fathers owning slaves. Right. And that doesn't take away the truth that. Toil, concubines. Yeah.
Yeah. The other one I think I read, oh, it was a Martin Luther had a lot of anti-Semitic views.
Yes. Yep. So anyways, but that doesn't change what they said, what they said can still be true.
Right. I think my response to when all of this, when anything like this happens as a,
as a man, as a Christian, as a husband, as a dad is to, to always let it put a little more fear of
God in me. I'm like, man, Lord, I, it doesn't, it makes me more scared. Like, Oh my goodness.
I remember when I was confronting a dad at family camp who was planning on leaving his family to
pursue this woman and how just the mess it was going to make of his family. I was obviously upset
by it and angered by kind of his obstinate attitude, but I went home and I think a couple
of my sons were at home and I just gathered them up. I said, you guys, can we just pray? I've just,
this really just scared me that this guy who knows all of this truth can still be doing this
stubbornly. And I don't want to ever get to that point where I could do that. Cause I just want to
be scared that I could fall too, but by the grace of God, um, for any of us. Right. Yeah. Right.
That's, that's I, I, yeah, I, I know how flawed I am. Right. Um, I know how sinful I can be. And yet
I teach on Sunday mornings, preach from the Bible on Sunday mornings, and I'm counting on God's word
and his spirit to be what speaks to people. Um, cause even if other people don't know what I wrestle
with or struggle with, although I'm not very secretive about it, but you know, I don't, you
know, if someone saw me scarfing that third or fourth, uh, by the way, did you know, you'll know
that them, they now make zebra cake rolls. Sorry, I shouldn't have told you then not just zebra cake
cakes now, but they make rolls speaking, speaking of scarfing three, three of something at a sitting.
And so I could imagine somebody seeing me scarf down that third one and go like,
I don't know if I should listen to him talk about self-control like him teaching about what the
Bible says about self-control. I don't know that he's the expert. I'm not, uh, Bible, however,
is God's word speaks about those things expertly and into our lives. I just,
I'm not always the best at following them either. And so we even talked, I even talked about how on
Sunday, the issue of prayer, like it's not surprising to me that our churches, you know,
kind of in one of the places where we struggle sometimes is in regards to prayer corporately,
because that's not one of my strong suits in the faith. And I need to be led in that.
And so, you know, we got to continue to work on those things. I'm, I'm, anyway, I'm just,
that's my concern. I don't want people to fall away because Christians fall away.
And, and again, I don't know if he's struggling and that's the only issue here and he's fallen.
Okay. Well, we can love him through that. Or if he's been a con artist,
using his position at the church as an opportunity to hurt people,
which means he's a sinner and I can love him and would like for that to change for him. Um,
either way, um, I, I agree. I want to encourage people to turn to Christ, um, when our heroes
fall, not, not, not to just other heroes. Anyway, if I can add to two related, uh, John Piper quotes,
because I think they're both so good. One of them was sparked in my mind. Chris, when you mentioned
prayer, he says, if prayer doesn't come easily for you, consider yourself normally fallen and
sinful, like the rest of us, and then fight. Um, like that's just it. And then another one that he
said is being born again, doesn't mean that you have no bad desires. It means that you're at war
with them. That's exactly. Just to be reminded, like, of course I have these desires. Of course,
it's going to be a battle on this side of heaven. But if I could do a plug for this again, and I did
this last time we talked for both of our churches, the region program, the regeneration program
is specifically there to help you learn how to bring your sin to the light and be accountable
and find your identity in Christ. And it's not just for major addictions that we think of it.
Literally is for everyone that we all need to be confessing our sin and keeping it in the light
there. And so both of those programs are available at South spring and at watermark and they're just
so helpful. They absolutely are. Yeah. And then last thing I was going to say is Chris, uh, shared
the, I was thinking about this driving into work today and I, and I, I feel like every time this
happens or this type of thing comes to light, what, what you have said for years is a secret life of
sin or sorry, a secret life of prayer will protect you from a secret life of sin. And so I feel like,
vice versa. Yeah, exactly. Exactly. Yeah. Yeah. And so that, that was even more just like convicting
to me of like, okay, the Lord can use this even to, yeah, even to convict me and, and like spark
that fear of like, okay, remembering who I am, that I am just a human and that I need him all the more.
Yep. So true. Very cool. Well, thank you guys for the time. That's, you know, if you don't mind,
I'd love to pray for real quickly. Let's say a quick prayer for Aaron and, and for his family,
I know his, I think his wife is also pretty well known in the community, Jamie, Ivy, and for
Austin stone. So if we could, let's, let's pray for them. And, and, uh, and then we can be
done with this, but man, just encourage people don't, don't lose heart because humans, it turns
out need a savior. Father, we're so grateful for this time. Thanks for Chris being available to
hang out today. Pre-continued bless all that he's doing over there at watermark and Lord,
as these churches, um, man, these churches, uh, grow and have further influence. There's going to be
issues like this that happen because we are failed and flawed humans. And that's not an
excuse. We're not saying, um, so we're not going to have to try or, you know, when we blow it,
don't hold us accountable. We warned you, we were messed up. That's, that's not what we're
talking about. We're, Lord, I pray that you would hold us fast, that you would help us to be faithful,
that we would stick and stand. Um, as we talked about this weekend at our D now,
Lord, that we would be standing and that when the battle has, has raged and there are corpses laying
all around, we're still standing. Um, in all regards to the faith you've called us to, um,
I want to lift up in particular, um, Aaron and his wife, Jamie, and I don't know if they've got
kids. I think they probably do. And I, I pray your faithfulness that you would speak comfort
into them somehow, Lord, that what would happen is what would need to happen, that justice would
be done and mercy would be lived out and grace would be poured onto all, um, in a way that,
Lord, I know that they just cannot imagine the way their lives have changed now. And so, um, Lord, I,
I know the churches are going to mess up stuff like this and humans are and pastors are and so
many are. And so I'll, I, Lord, I pray for your faithfulness as we unpack all of this in our own
lives. When we see those who we love and appreciate, when we see them fall or when we see them fail,
or sometimes when they turn out not to be at all who or whether we thought they were, Lord, I pray
that our eyes would be come back to you, not to the storms, um, or even to the water that we're
walking on Lord, but on always back to you. And so we trust in you, the author and finisher of our
faith and is in the name of your perfect son that we pray. Amen. Thank you for joining us for this
episode of Reconstructed Faith. If you enjoyed what you heard or were challenged, please leave
us a review. It'll help other people find us. If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear
discussed, shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource
of South Spring Baptist Church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
